root:
Infobox Planet name = Calypso image = [[Image:Calypso image PIA07633.jpg]] bgcolour = #a0ffa0 discovery = yes discoverer = [[Dan Pascu|Pascu]], [[P. Kenneth Seidelmann|Seidelmann]],
[[William A. Baum|Baum]] and [[Douglas G. Currie|Currie]] discovered = March 13, 1980 semimajor = 294,619 km eccentricity = 0.000 period = 1.887802 dref[http://exp.arc.nasa.gov/downloads/celestia/data/solarsys.ssc NASA Celestia] inclination = 1.56° (to Saturn's equator) satellite_of = [[Saturn]] physical_characteristics = yes dimensions = 30 × 23 × 14 kmref name="Porco2006"{{cite journal | author= [[Carolyn C. Porco|Porco, C. C.]]; ''et al.''| title= ''Physical Characteristics and Possible Accretionary Origins for Saturn's Small Satellites''| journal= Bulletin of the American Astronomical Society| year= 2006| volume= 37| pages= 768| url=http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2006/pdf/2289.pdf}} mean_radius = 10.7 ± 1.0 kmref name="Porco2006" rotation = [[synchronous rotation|synchronous]] axial_tilt = zero albedo = 1.34 ± 0.10 ([[geometric albedo|geometric]])ref name=Verbiscer[[Anne Verbiscer|Verbiscer, A.]]; [[Richard French|French, R.]]; [[Mark Showalter|Showalter, M.]]; and [[Paul Helfenstein|Helfenstein, P.]]; [http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/315/5813/815 ''Enceladus: Cosmic Graffiti Artist Caught in the Act''], Science, Vol. 315, No. 5813 (February 9, 2007), p. 815 (supporting online material, table S1) adjectives = Calypsonian '''Calypso''' (pronEngkəˈlɪpsoʊ respellkəLIPsoh, or as in Greek ''Καλυψώ)'' is a [[natural satellite|moon]] of [[Saturn]]. It was discovered by [[Dan Pascu|Pascu]], [[P. Kenneth Seidelmann|Seidelmann]], [[William A. Baum|Baum]] and [[Douglas G. Currie|Currie]] in 1980 from ground-based observations, and was provisionally designated '''nowrapS/1980 S 25'''.ref[http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iauc/03400/03496.html IAUC 3496: ''Satellites of Saturn''] July 31, 1980 (discovery) Several other apparitions of it were recorded in the following months: nowrapS/1980 S 29, nowrapS/1980 S 30,ref[http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iauc/03500/03549.html IAUC 3549: ''Satellites of Saturn''] December 11, 1980 nowrapS/1980 S 32,ref[http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iauc/03600/03605.html IAUC 3605: ''Satellites of Saturn''] May 18, 1981 and nowrapS/1981 S 2.ref[http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iauc/03500/03593.html IAUC 3593: ''Satellites of Saturn''] April 16, 1981 In 1983 it was officially named after [[Calypso (mythology)|Calypso]] of [[Greek mythology]]refTransactions of the International Astronomical Union, Vol. XVIIIA, 1982 (confirms Janus, names Epimetheus, Telesto, Calypso) (mentioned in [http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iauc/03800/03872.html IAUC 3872: ''Satellites of Jupiter and Saturn''], September 30, 1983). It is also designated as '''nowrapSaturn XIV''' or '''Tethys C'''. Calypso is co-orbital with the moon [[Tethys (moon)|Tethys]], and resides in Tethys' trailing [[Lagrangian point]] (L5) 60 degrees behind Tethys. This relationship was first identified by Seidelmann ''et al.'' in 1981.ref name="Seidelmann1981"Seidelmann, P. K.; [[Robert S. Harrington|Harrington, R. S.]]; Pascu, D.; Baum, W. A.; Currie, D. G.; [[James A. Westphal|Westphal, J. A.]]; and [[G. Edward Danielson|Danielson, G. E.]]; [http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-bib_query?bibcode=1981Icar...47..282S&db_key=AST&data_type=HTML&format=&high=45eb6e10af20904 ''Saturn Satellite Observations and Orbits from the 1980 Ring Plane Crossing''], Icarus, Vol. 47 (August 1981), pp. 282–287 The moon [[Telesto (moon)|Telesto]] also resides in the other (leading) lagrangian point of Tethys, 60 degrees in the other direction from Tethys. [[Image:Calypso moon.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Calypso as seen by [[Voyager 2]]]] Like many other small Saturnian moons and small asteroids, Calypso is irregularly shaped, has overlapping large craters, and appears to also have loose surface material capable of smoothing the craters' appearance. Its surface is one of the most reflective (at visual wavelengths) in the solar system, with a visual [[geometric albedo]] of 1.34.ref name=Verbiscer This very high albedo is the result of the sandblasting of particles from Saturn's E-ring, a faint ring composed of small, water-ice particle generated by Enceladus' south polar geysers. Not to be confused with [[asteroid]] [[53 Kalypso]]. ==References== reflist ==External links== *[http://solarsystem.nasa.gov/planets/profile.cfm?Object=Sat_Calypso Calypso Profile] by [http://solarsystem.nasa.gov NASA's Solar System Exploration] *[http://www.planetary.org/explore/topics/saturn/calypso.html The Planetary Society: Calypso] ==See also== *[[List of moons]] Moons of Saturnstate=uncollapsed DEFAULTSORT:Calypso (Moon) [[Category:Moons of Saturn]] [[als:Calypso (Mond)]] [[bg:Калипсо (спътник)]] [[ca:Calipso (satèl·lit)]] [[cs:Calypso (měsíc)]] [[cy:Calypso (lloeren)]] [[da:Calypso (måne)]] [[de:Calypso (Mond)]] [[el:Καλυψώ (δορυφόρος)]] [[es:Calipso (satélite)]] [[fr:Calypso (lune)]] [[hr:Kalipso (mjesec)]] [[it:Calipso (astronomia)]] [[la:Calypso (satelles)]] [[lt:Kalipsė (palydovas)]] [[nl:Calypso (maan)]] [[ja:カリプソ (衛星)]] [[nn:Saturnmånen Calypso]] [[pl:Kalipso (księżyc)]] [[ro:Calypso (satelit)]] [[ru:Калипсо (спутник)]] [[simple:Calypso (moon)]] [[sk:Calypso (mesiac)]] [[sl:Kalipso (luna)]] [[fi:Calypso (kuu)]] [[sv:Calypso (måne)]] [[uk:Каліпсо (супутник)]] [[zh:土卫十四]]
